subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Terminal unstressed -ior & terminal -ion (with y-sound)
msgSnippet: Hello all, As a counterpoint to what’s been said so far, I’m an American English speaker and I use nearly all of the sounds that Quickscript represents. I
messageBody:
Hello all,

 

As a counterpoint to what�s been said so far, I�m an American English speaker and I use nearly all of the sounds that Quickscript represents. I have been writing in Quickscript for about 8 years and I use it for about %90 of my daily writing.  Also I�m the person who built and uploaded the quickscript dictionary here. It is a American English dictionary and it surely uses all of the sounds.  The �awe�, the �ah�, ...

 

I will agree that there are distinct differences between British and American English, but I think Quickscript handles all of the sounds in a fine manner and I do not see any loss in having a few letters in it that are not used by all.

kyudosha <kyudosha@...> wrote:
Yeah, it's a Brit thing.  Because it was written by a British-
speaking man, Quickscript does indeed show some bias towards the
traditional English way of pronounciation.  "Visual", for example, is
spelled in the manual thusly: 10/26/12/17+40/36/24, whereas an
American would be inclined to spell it 10/26/_14_/...

This bias also makes for some interesting differences when using
letters 32-34, which to our ears are all pronounced the same.  As
near as I can tell, there should be no need for an American to use
letter 34 at ALL, save that it abbreviates "on".  I have made this
choice based upon my research so far.  34 is useful to American
english speakers not as an "ah" sound, but as the o-spelled sound
that directly preceeds "r" in such words as "or" "north" "sore",
etc... examples from the Quickscript manual confirm this usage. 

Letter 20 is also unused by Americans, but serves as a nice
abbreviation for "what". In fact, I would be inclined to say that
both 20 AND 34 could be stricken from the alphabet for all english
speakers and Readscript would not suffer because of it.

For my purposes, all "ah" sounds I spell with 32, all "o[r]" sounds I
spell with 33, and 34 is utterly unused, save to abbreviate "on",
which I am considering dropping as well.

This will doubtless cause some people to get up-in-arms, but I am
also interested in the discourse, and if I am wrong, then this will
not be the first time. ;)

-Andy

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "steveb_667" <sbartok1632@e...>
wrote:
> I am curious as to why terminal unstressed -ior is spelt with
letters
> #26+#36+#25 & terminal -ion (with y-sound) is spelt with letters
> #17+#36+#23. The examples "senior" & "junior" used in the Quikscript
> manual for unstressed terminal -ior have significant "y" sounds in
> them & this is indicated in the dictionary pronunciation key as
well.
> Is this simply a case of British - American difference? The example
> "furrier" seems to be where the spelling of terminal unstressed -ior
> (#26+#36+#25) is being aimed at, even though that clearly does not
> have the "y" sound that "senior" & "junior" have.
>
> So, would this be an acceptable alteration of the rule?
>
> Terminal unstressed -ior (with Y-sound) ... #17+#36+#25
>
> Examples : senior, junior, behavior
>
> If this issue has been brought up previously, I apologize for
bringing
> it up again. I could not find this issue in previous messages. Thank
> you.
